title: BlackRock's bond chief oversees $1.7 trillion and only sleeps 4 hours a night. He outlines his 2 favorite opportunities in a market being reshaped by tech and shifting demographics.
text:
Rick Rieder, the chief investment officer of global fixed income and head of global allocation at BlackRock — where he oversees $1.7 trillion — thinks it'd be wise for investors to shape their investments around aging demographics and disruptive technologies going forward.

He's identifies gold and real estate as two areas he's particularly excited about in today's market environment.

He also says that sleep "is a waste of time."

Click here for more BI Prime stories.

When it comes to investing, hindsight is always 20/20.

Trends and narratives that were nebulous in real-time, quickly become crystal-clear when looking in the rearview mirror.

But this isn't always the case — and sometimes the secular trends that are responsible for shaping the future happen to end up right in front of the viewfinder.

Rick Rieder, chief investment officer of global fixed income and head of global allocation at BlackRock, thinks he's spotted just that. And he should know. He spends the majority of his time watching markets, and only sleeps four hours a night. He even goes as far as to call the latter allotment as a "waste of time."

"There are two influences that I think are the biggest ones — and I think that if you just got these two right, it's the key to investing going forward," he said on The Bid, a market events and investing ideas podcast by BlackRock. "It's demographics and technology."

Let's get things started with demographics.

Rieder thinks that slowing birth rates and an aging boomer cohort will weigh on global growth for a long time. It's a conversation that keeps inching it's way into the limelight, as the baby boomer's gear up for an ill-prepared retirement.

"It has huge ramifications," he said. "Global growth is going to stay low for a long time. These interest rates are going to stay low for a really long time."

He continued: "Central banks have to keep rates low, because you don't create enough organic growth."

Read more: Why BlackRock's $1.7 trillion bond chief gets up at 3:30 a.m.

In addition to slowing growth, Rieder references the soon-to-be insatiable appetite for steady, reliable income — and leans on the needs of pension funds and insurance companies to bolster his view.

In order to meet demand and cover liabilities, these institutions have to have access to massive amounts of income-generating assets. More demand equates to higher prices — and investors are already paying sky-high prices for assets that are yielding peanuts or nothing at all.

Rieder refers to this notion as "a really, really big deal."

Next up is technology.

It's no secret that technology is upending the world we live in. Entire industries — retail and energy to name a few — have been surmounted by technological disruptions. And the trend shows no sign of stopping.

"Make sure that you're in the right industries, make sure you're in the right places — but make sure that you're in those places that are not going to get disrupted, because technology is changing so darn fast," he said. "Technology does not grow in a 45 degree angle, like a smooth graph."

He continued: "It stays low and then it explodes higher."

Where he sees opportunity today

To that end, Rieder has identified two places where he sees budding prospects that are ripe for the picking: Gold and real estate.

"For the first time in a long time in many years, I'm actually excited about gold again," he said. "When you depreciate the currency in other parts of the world — because you just print money, or negative interest rates — gold tends to work really well."

And gold prices have been on a tear as of late as investors flood into the precious metal amidst heightened uncertainty and a plethora of stimulative central bank policies. In fact, since the start of 2019, SPDR Gold Shares ETF (GLD) is up over 21%.

He sees similar allure in the real estate market.

"I think they're parts of the real estate market that I still think I really attractive," he said. "I think the residential real estate market — whether it's a direct investment, whether it's tangential in a home builders — the equity in peoples' homes is the highest it's been in years and years and years."

An investor looking to adopt a similar approach could purchase a broad basket of home builders like the iShares U.S. Home Construction ETF (ITB), or SPDR S&P Homebuilders ETF (XHB).
description: Rick Rieder, CIO of global fixed income and head of global allocation at BlackRock, is excited about two asset classes in particular.
